Description: Provides free APIs for real-time and historical market data (stocks, forex, commodities, cryptocurrencies), plus over 50 technical indicators, supporting multiple data formats[1][2]. Ideal for retrieving financial time series for research and algorithmic trading.
Potential Use Cases: Backtesting trading strategies; technical indicator analysis; market efficiency studies
Time Span: Varies by asset (historical data for many assets, up to decades)

Description: Collection of datasets from AQR Capital Management’s research publications, covering topics like factor investing, commodities, and alternative strategies[3]. Often includes factor returns and strategy data, enabling replication of academic studies in finance.
Potential Use Cases: Analyzing factor premia (e.g. value, momentum); replicating quantitative strategies; portfolio construction
Update Frequency: Periodic updates (aligned with research publications; often annual or quarterly)

Description: Offers extensive cryptocurrency data including historical prices, market capitalizations, and on-chain metrics (e.g. blockchain network activity)[4]. Useful for analyzing the rapidly evolving cryptocurrency markets and their financial implications[4].
Potential Use Cases: Cryptocurrency market analysis; studying network activity vs asset prices; volatility and risk comparison between crypto and traditional assets
Time Span: Since inception of each cryptocurrency (e.g. Bitcoin from 2009)

Description: Provides a free API and web platform for cryptocurrency market data, including prices, trading volume, rankings, and exchange data for thousands of crypto assets. Similar to CoinMetrics, it offers insight into cryptocurrency market trends[4].
Potential Use Cases: Tracking cryptoasset performance; comparing price movements across exchanges; research on crypto market efficiency

Description: An API-based service providing current and historical foreign exchange rates for numerous currency pairs. Enables currency conversion and analysis of FX rate movements[5].
Potential Use Cases: Examining exchange rate dynamics; testing Covered Interest Parity; impact of macro events on FX rates
Time Span: ~2000s–present (historical rates available; exact start varies by currency)

Description: Hosted by UBC Sauder, provides historical exchange rates data (daily, monthly) for a wide range of currencies. Useful for long-term FX studies and currency conversions[5].
Potential Use Cases: Historical exchange rate analysis; testing international parity conditions; impact of crises on currency values
Update Frequency: Daily (updated regularly with new exchange rate data)
Source/Institution: University of British Columbia (Sauder) – Pacific Exchange Rate Service (Werner Antweiler)

Description: Provides global factor portfolio returns and stock characteristics across 93 countries, based on Jensen, Kelly & Pedersen (2023)[6][7]. Supports research on international factor investing and replication of asset pricing studies.
Potential Use Cases: Cross-country factor comparisons; testing asset pricing models globally; examining economic condition effects on factor returns[8]
Update Frequency: Periodic (static dataset with occasional academic updates)
Data Format/Access: CSV downloads (plus code and docs; some data via WRDS)
Authors (if provided): Bryan Kelly, Turney Duff Jens [Check Correction] Jensen, Bryan Kelly, Lasse Pedersen (2023) [JKP]

Description: A public Google Sheet consolidating various financial data: equity index prices, macroeconomic indicators, industry metrics, etc., into a single resource[9][10]. Serves as a convenient one-stop dataset for broad financial analysis.
Potential Use Cases: Preliminary data exploration for thesis topics; quick access to multi-category financial data; teaching tool for data analysis
Time Span: Mixed (various series with their own historical ranges)

Description: Collection of asset pricing factor datasets (e.g. Fama-French 3/5 factors: size, value, momentum, profitability, investment, etc.) for U.S. and global markets. A cornerstone resource for empirical finance research[11], widely used for testing asset pricing models and portfolio analysis.
Potential Use Cases: Evaluating factor model performance (e.g. FF3 vs FF5); constructing custom factors; analyzing risk premia over time
Time Span: 1926–present (for US factors; shorter for some international)
Data Format/Access: CSV data files (web download); also via library websites

Description: Platform offering datasets and replication code for asset pricing research, including test asset returns and predictive signals replicated from academic literature[12]. Aims to increase transparency and reproducibility in financial economics.
Potential Use Cases: Replicating published asset pricing studies; validating new factors; educational use for learning asset pricing techniques
Region/Coverage: Global (primarily U.S. market focus for many datasets)
Time Span: Varies (historical data as per original studies)
Update Frequency: Irregular (updated when new studies/data are added)
Source/Institution: Open Source Asset Pricing community (led by academics)

Description: Resource with data and code to replicate corporate bond asset pricing studies[13]. Includes bond-level panel data with various predictors and factors, facilitating research on corporate bond markets and fixed income asset pricing.
Potential Use Cases: Corporate bond return prediction; studying bond risk premia; extending equity factor models to bond markets
Time Span: ~1973–present (typical coverage aligning with corporate bond data availability)
Source/Institution: Open Bond Asset Pricing project (academic initiative)

Description: Comprehensive database tracking credit rating changes over time from major agencies (Moody’s, S&P, Fitch). Includes historical rating transitions and timelines, useful for analyzing credit risk and rating-based investment strategies.
Potential Use Cases: Studying impact of rating changes on bond/stock prices; default probability research; credit risk modeling
Update Frequency: Updated periodically (as new ratings changes occur)

Description: Offers APIs for real-time and historical data on stocks, forex, cryptocurrencies, ETFs, and indices. Supports multiple data formats and integration with various programming languages, providing a flexible solution for market data retrieval.
Potential Use Cases: Building trading algorithms; real-time market monitoring dashboards; multi-asset price analysis
Time Span: Varies by asset (historical depth differs per instrument)

Dataset Name: EDGAR – Emissions Database for Global Atmospheric Research
Description: Global database of anthropogenic greenhouse gas and air pollutant emissions[14]. Provides country and sector-level emissions data, offering insights into environmental impact by region[15]. Widely used to link emissions data with economic and financial analysis.
Potential Use Cases: Studying corporate carbon exposure vs financial performance[16]; analyzing impacts of emissions regulations on markets
Update Frequency: Annual updates (with a lag for data processing)
Data Format/Access: CSV and database query (via EU JRC website)

Description: U.S. database of industrial pollution and toxic chemical releases, reported annually by facilities[17]. Used to assess firms’ environmental performance and regulatory compliance[18]. Provides detailed data on chemicals, quantities, and locations of releases.
Potential Use Cases: Linking pollution data to firm stock performance[18]; research on environmental regulation impact; community health and investment studies
Data Format/Access: CSV downloads, EPA data portal (online query)

Description: Dataset measuring firms’ exposure to climate change risks and opportunities, derived from textual analysis of corporate disclosures (e.g. earnings calls)[19]. Allows researchers to gauge how sensitive individual firms are to climate-related issues.
Potential Use Cases: Analyzing climate risk disclosure effects on stock volatility[20]; studying investor reactions to climate news
Data Format/Access: CSV dataset on OSF (Open Science Framework)
Authors (if provided): Authors: Ilhan, Sautner, Vilkov (as per associated paper)

Dataset Name: ECB Household Finance and Consumption Survey (HFCS)
Description: European household-level survey covering income, wealth, consumption, and debt across Eurozone countries[21]. Provides microdata to understand financial behavior, inequality, and the impact of monetary policy on households[22].
Potential Use Cases: Research on wealth distribution and consumption in Europe[23]; analyzing household debt and financial stability[21]

Description: ECB Survey on the Access to Finance of Enterprises, focusing on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Europe[24]. Captures data on financing needs, credit access, and obstacles faced by SMEs[24]. Invaluable for understanding the business financing environment.
Potential Use Cases: Studying credit constraints and SME growth[24]; analyzing effectiveness of credit policies; SME financing trends over cycles
Data Format/Access: CSV datasets (aggregated results) on ECB website

Description: Surveys by the European Investment Bank covering investment activities, infrastructure needs, innovation, and firm performance across EU countries[25]. Includes specialized topics like digitalization and climate adaptation, informing research on sustainable finance and development[25].
Potential Use Cases: Examining SME investment under low interest rates[26]; green finance adoption in Europe[27]; infrastructure investment gaps analysis
Data Format/Access: Survey reports and microdata (some public summary data)

Dataset Name: Euro Area Monetary Policy Event-Study Database
Description: Database of European Central Bank monetary policy decisions and associated financial market reactions[28]. It documents policy announcement dates and the immediate impact on asset prices, enabling analysis of monetary policy transmission in the Euro area.
Potential Use Cases: Studying market reactions to ECB policy announcements[29]; comparing conventional vs unconventional policy effects on bonds and stocks

Description: Official daily reference exchange rates for the euro against various currencies, published by the ECB[30]. Provides a consistent source for Euro FX rates, often used for economic analysis and currency risk studies.
Potential Use Cases: Analyzing exchange rate movements in relation to ECB policy[31]; covered interest parity tests involving the euro; foreign trade impact assessments
Data Format/Access: CSV/XML daily data (ECB website and API)

Description: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics survey on household expenditures, income, and demographics[32]. Provides detailed microdata on spending patterns, used to study consumption behavior and cost-of-living trends[33].
Potential Use Cases: Analyzing consumer spending during recessions[34]; examining income inequality effects on consumption[34]; inflation and cost-of-living research

Description: Triennial survey by the U.S. Federal Reserve detailing household balance sheets, including assets, debts, pensions, income, and demographics[35][36]. Focuses on wealth distribution and financial health of households.
Potential Use Cases: Research on wealth inequality in the U.S.; analyzing household debt and financial vulnerability[36]; calibrating models of consumer finance

Description: Biannual survey of U.S. residents covering opinions, attitudes, and behaviors on various topics[37]. Often used in finance research to link social trends (trust, risk tolerance, etc.) with economic and financial behavior[38].
Potential Use Cases: Studying financial literacy and investment behavior[39]; examining social trust and risk-taking in financial decisions[39]

Description: An online longitudinal panel survey in the Netherlands, representative of the Dutch population[40]. Collects rich household data on assets, income, and preferences. High-quality source for studying Dutch household finances and social factors.
Potential Use Cases: Investigating household asset and income relationships in the Netherlands[41]; studying housing wealth effects (e.g. during COVID)[41]

Dataset Name: University of Michigan Survey of Consumers
Description: Long-running survey capturing U.S. consumer sentiment, expectations, and attitudes toward economic conditions[42]. Often summarized as the Index of Consumer Sentiment. Widely used as an indicator of consumer confidence and spending propensity.
Potential Use Cases: Linking consumer sentiment to stock market returns[43]; studying how economic uncertainty influences household decisions[43]; macro forecasting

Description: Weekly survey by the American Association of Individual Investors gauging retail investor sentiment (percent bullish, bearish, neutral)[44]. Provides a sentiment index often used as a contrarian indicator or for analyzing behavioral biases in markets.
Potential Use Cases: Examining sentiment’s impact on short-term market movements[45]; studying behavioral biases in retail investing[45]; contrarian strategy development
Data Format/Access: Results published on AAII website (CSV available)

Description: A collection of indices measuring economic uncertainty (e.g. Policy Uncertainty Index by Baker, Bloom & Davis)[46]. These indices are based on factors like policy news, geopolitical events, and market volatility[46]. Used to study how uncertainty affects economic decisions and markets.
Potential Use Cases: Investigating the impact of uncertainty on corporate investment[47]; studying cross-border investment under policy uncertainty; forecasting recessions
Authors (if provided): Scott Baker, Nicholas Bloom, Steven Davis (creators)

Description: Country-level dataset of cultural dimension scores (e.g. Individualism, Uncertainty Avoidance, Long-Term Orientation)[48]. Widely used to examine how cultural norms influence economic behavior, corporate governance, and financial decisions[48].
Potential Use Cases: Relating cultural traits to financial literacy and behaviors[49]; studying cultural distance effects on cross-border M&A returns[49]
Data Format/Access: CSV data available from Hofstede site
Source/Institution: Geert Hofstede, Gert Jan Hofstede, Michael Minkov

Description: Measures strength of social connectedness between geographic areas based on Facebook friendship links[50]. Provides an index of cross-region social ties, useful for understanding how social networks may influence economic and financial interactions.
Potential Use Cases: Analyzing how social networks affect stock market integration and capital flows[51]; studying information transmission in finance via social connections
Time Span: 2018–present (using Facebook data at points in time)
Data Format/Access: CSV data via Humanitarian Data Exchange (OCHA)

Description: Global survey on social, political, and cultural values, with data on trust, beliefs, attitudes, etc.[52]. Often linked to economic outcomes to study how societal norms relate to financial development and behavior[53].
Potential Use Cases: Examining the role of trust in financial market participation[54]; studying cultural values vs corporate social responsibility outcomes[55]

Description: Provides geographic distance measures and related variables for country pairs (e.g. distances between capitals, common language, colonial ties)[56]. Often used in international trade and finance to study how distance and geography affect economic interactions[57].
Potential Use Cases: Analyzing effect of distance on FDI and trade flows[58]; examining how shocks like COVID alter distance vs. M&A relationships[58]
Time Span: Static (distance and geography do not change; data reflects historical ties as of ~2000s)
Update Frequency: Static (periodically updated for new country definitions)
Data Format/Access: CSV data files (download from CEPII site)
Authors (if provided): Thierry Mayer, Soledad Zignago (authors of distance dataset)

Description: Datasets from Bram van der Kroft’s research focusing on sustainability in real estate and corporate behavior[83]. Includes data on green building renovations and firm-level sustainability initiatives and performance[83].
Potential Use Cases: Studying financial returns to sustainable real estate investments; analyzing how corporate sustainability aspirations affect performance
Update Frequency: Static (data as used in specific papers)

Description: Annual dataset (2004–2020) on regulatory environment across countries, covering ease of starting a business, getting credit, enforcing contracts, etc.[59]. Although the Doing Business report was discontinued in 2021, historical data remain valuable for studying regulatory impact[60].
Potential Use Cases: Investigating how business regulations relate to entrepreneurship and growth; examining leverage vs ease of business start-up[61][62]; cross-country investment climate comparisons
Authors (if provided): Simeon Djankov et al. (original methodology authors)

Description: Global database of 26,000+ mass disasters (natural and technological) from 1900 to present[63]. Records disaster dates, types, locations, and impacts (fatalities, damages)[64]. Used to analyze the economic and financial impact of disasters worldwide.
Potential Use Cases: Studying global financial market reactions to major disasters[65]; assessing disaster risk on sovereign credit risk[65]; insurance and catastrophe bond research
Data Format/Access: Online database (query tool, data download for researchers)
Source/Institution: CRED (Univ. of Louvain) – Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters

Description: An open-source, unified macroeconomic dataset combining data from 32 major sources (IMF, World Bank, OECD, etc.) with 78 historical datasets to create comprehensive annual time series for 46 variables across 243 countries[66]. Continuously updated resource for long-run international macro data.
Potential Use Cases: Long-horizon cross-country growth studies; historical analysis of macroeconomic trends; validating economic history models (e.g. 19th century growth vs openness[67])
Time Span: 19th century–present (data from 1800s onward for many series)
Source/Institution: Global Macro Database project (Karsten Müller et al.)
Authors (if provided): Karsten Müller, Chenzi Xu, Mohamed Lehbib, Ziliang Chen (2023)

Dataset Name: Heritage Foundation Index of Economic Freedom
Description: Annual index scoring countries on economic institutions: property rights, regulatory efficiency, trade freedom, etc.[68]. Offers a snapshot of policy and governance environments, useful for evaluating investment climate and growth prospects[68].
Potential Use Cases: Analyzing impact of economic freedom on FDI and venture capital inflows[69]; studying links between regulatory efficiency and financial market development[69]
Data Format/Access: Scores online; full data in CSV via Heritage site
Authors (if provided): Terry Miller, Anthony Kim (annual report authors)

Description: Firm-level dataset on U.S. lobbying activities and corresponding congressional bills[70]. Includes lobbying expenditure amounts, targeted bill identifiers, and firms involved[71]. Enables analysis of corporate political engagement and its financial effects.
Potential Use Cases: Studying how corporate lobbying affects firm performance[72]; analyzing market reactions to lobbying around legislation[72]; political influence on industries
Time Span: 1999–present (lobbying reports under the Lobbying Disclosure Act)
Data Format/Access: CSV data sets (report-level, issue-level, etc., via site)
Authors (if provided): In Song Kim (MIT) and colleagues (LobbyView creators, 2018)

Description: Historical macroeconomic and financial data compiled by the Jordà-Schularick-Taylor Macrohistory Lab[73]. Includes long-term series on GDP, credit, housing prices, interest rates, banking crises, etc., across many countries, enabling study of financial system evolution[74].
Potential Use Cases: Analyzing housing price dynamics during historical crises[75]; studying long-run effects of monetary policy on financial stability[75]; macro-financial regime comparisons
Time Span: 1870–present (annual data for many variables through modern era)
Authors (if provided): Òscar Jordà, Moritz Schularick, Alan M. Taylor (2017)

Description: Dataset of quantitative tightening events and measures, focusing on central bank balance sheet reductions and their market impact[76]. Tracks episodes of major central banks (e.g. Federal Reserve) unwinding asset purchases, useful for studying policy normalization effects.
Potential Use Cases: Examining effects of balance sheet reduction on bond yields[77]; analyzing stock market reactions to quantitative tightening announcements[77]; comparing QE vs QT impacts
Region/Coverage: U.S. (and other major economies for QT episodes)
Update Frequency: Updated when new QT events occur
Source/Institution: Compiled by Mark Dijkstra (or source cited in file)

Dataset Name: SHELDUS (Spatial Hazard Events and Losses Database)
Description: U.S. county-level dataset of natural hazard events (thunderstorms, hurricanes, floods, wildfires, etc.) and their direct losses (property damage, crop loss, injuries, fatalities)[78]. Covers events from 1960 onward, providing granular insight into local disaster impacts.
Potential Use Cases: Analyzing the economic impact of natural disasters on local communities; insurance loss modeling; studying credit risk in disaster-prone areas[79]
Update Frequency: Continuous (updated as new hazard events occur)
Data Format/Access: Online database (query by county/event; data export)
Authors (if provided): Data team at ASU’s Center for Emergency Mgmt

Description: Annual index ranking countries by perceived public-sector corruption (0 = highly corrupt to 100 = very clean)[80]. Based on expert assessments and surveys, it is used to study the relationship between governance quality and economic or financial outcomes[80].
Potential Use Cases: Investigating how corruption levels affect foreign direct investment[81]; studying corporate governance and firm performance in high-corruption environments[81]
Data Format/Access: Index scores downloadable (CSV) on TI website

Description: Repository of datasets from Prof. Amit Goyal’s research, including well-known predictors for stock returns (e.g. dividend yields, earnings yields, interest rates) and bond returns[82]. These are foundational for studies on return predictability and asset allocation.
Potential Use Cases: Testing equity premium prediction models; exploring new return predictors; replicating Goyal & Welch (2008) results
Time Span: ~1926–present (varies by predictor, many start mid-20th century)
Update Frequency: Occasional updates (data through early 2020s for some series)
Authors (if provided): Amit Goyal (with Ivo Welch for equity predictors)

Description: Repository of datasets and code from Prof. Grigory Vilkov’s work, covering option pricing, volatility surfaces, and risk management[84]. Enables replication of studies on derivative markets and volatility risk.
Potential Use Cases: Analyzing volatility risk premiums; replicating option pricing models; studying hedging strategies performance
Data Format/Access: CSV data and code (on personal academic page)

Dataset Name: Intermediary Capital Ratio and Risk Factor (Zhiguo He)
Description: Dataset from Zhiguo He’s research on the intermediary asset pricing model, providing the intermediary capital ratio factor and related data[85]. Focuses on how broker-dealer balance sheet conditions drive asset returns.
Potential Use Cases: Testing intermediary asset pricing models; examining how dealer leverage (capital ratios) predicts asset price fluctuations; financial crisis analysis

Description: Data accompanying Prof. Robert F. Stambaugh’s influential studies on markets. Includes datasets on market efficiency, returns, and especially liquidity factors (e.g. Pastor-Stambaugh liquidity factor)[86]. Facilitates replication and further exploration of his work.
Potential Use Cases: Investigating the role of market liquidity in asset pricing; replicating stock predictability studies; analyzing anomalies identified by Stambaugh
Data Format/Access: CSV data files (via Wharton faculty page)

Description: Datasets from Vincent Bogousslavsky’s research on informed trading, high-frequency market dynamics, and auction pricing[87]. Includes measures like trading intensity, order imbalance volatility, etc., useful for analyzing intraday market behavior.
Potential Use Cases: Studying short-term reversal and momentum at high frequencies; evaluating how order imbalances affect prices; research on price formation during auctions
Data Format/Access: CSV data files (via personal GitHub pages)

Description: A massive database of over 816,000 economic and financial time series from various sources, maintained by the St. Louis Fed[88]. Covers macro indicators (GDP, CPI, employment), interest rates, financial markets, etc., with data from dozens of national and international agencies.
Potential Use Cases: Macroeconomic analysis and forecasting; financial market correlations with macro variables; quick access to historical economic data for research and teaching
Update Frequency: Daily/Weekly/Monthly (varies by series; many real-time updates)
Source/Institution: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis

Description: The World Bank’s primary collection of development statistics, with over 1,500 indicators on economic, social, and environmental topics for 200+ countries[89]. Provides decades of data (many series from 1960) on GDP, trade, education, health, poverty, and more, enabling global development research.
Potential Use Cases: Cross-country growth and development analysis; tracking progress on Sustainable Development Goals; examining how economic indicators relate to financial development
Data Format/Access: Online DataBank, CSV/Excel bulk download; API available

Description: A set of national accounts data providing comparable real GDP, productivity, and factor inputs for 183 countries from 1950 onward[90]. Allows cross-country and over-time comparisons of living standards and economic productivity under a consistent PPP-based framework[90].
Potential Use Cases: International comparisons of GDP per capita and productivity; long-run growth analysis; calibrating economic models with PPP-adjusted data
Update Frequency: Infrequent major releases (updated every few years)
Data Format/Access: Excel/Stata datasets (via University of Groningen site)
Authors (if provided): Robert C. Feenstra, Robert Inklaar, Marcel P. Timmer

Description: Extensive dataset of financial system characteristics for 214 economies, with 108 indicators on banking and markets, yearly from 1960–2021[91]. Metrics cover financial depth, access, efficiency, and stability for both financial institutions and markets[92], following the World Bank’s 4x2 framework.
Potential Use Cases: Benchmarking countries’ financial development; studying links between financial development and growth; analyzing effects of bank regulations across countries
Data Format/Access: Excel data files (via World Bank site)
Authors (if provided): Martin Cihák; Asli Demirgüç-Kunt; Erik Feyen; Ross Levine (2012)

Description: A collection of international financial datasets compiled by the BIS in cooperation with central banks[93]. Covers global banking activity (locational and consolidated bank statistics), credit to non-financial sectors, debt securities, exchange rates, derivatives turnover, and more. Designed to inform analysis of monetary and financial stability[93].
Potential Use Cases: Research on global liquidity and credit cycles; analysis of international banking flows; studying credit-to-GDP gaps for financial stability assessments; cross-country housing and debt comparisons
Region/Coverage: Global (multiple databases: 40+ countries in some, up to 180 in others)
Time Span: ~1960s–present (varies by dataset; credit series from 1960, banking stats from 1970s)
Data Format/Access: Online BIS Data Portal (CSV/XLS bulk downloads; API)

Dataset Name: Global Capital Allocation Project (GCAP)  Data & Code Repository
Description: Data and code repository to analyze global capital allocations by country, currency, and asset class; includes datasets linking traded securities to issuers ultimate parents (incl. tax-haven structures) and multiple replication packages.
Potential Use Cases: Cross-border portfolio holdings and currency denomination studies; tax-haven and offshore finance research; replication of GCAP papers and teaching modules
Region/Coverage: Global (includes Euro Area, China/offshore, U.S. fund holdings modules, etc.)
Time Span: Varies by dataset and paper (see README files on the data hub)
Update Frequency: Irregular (new datasets/releases posted to the data hub)
Data Format/Access: ZIP/TAR archives; XLS/DTA files; GitHub code repositories; README documentation
Authors (if provided): Matteo Maggiori; Jesse Schreger; Antonio Coppola; Hannah Firestone (and coauthors by dataset)

Description: SEC EDGAR provides free public access to corporate filings (e.g., registration statements, prospectuses, 10-K/10-Q/8-K) and search tools, including full-text search for filings since 2001.
Potential Use Cases: Firm fundamental and event research; textual analysis (MD&A/Risk Factors); constructing firm-level disclosure and governance measures
Region/Coverage: United States (SEC filers: public companies, funds, insiders, etc.)
Time Span: Electronic filings mandated starting in early 1993; full-text search coverage since 2001
Update Frequency: Continuous / real-time as filings are submitted
Data Format/Access: Web search & downloads; bulk data feeds; structured data (e.g., XBRL) and APIs via SEC data pages

Description: Open datasets with detailed firm demographic information (race and gender composition, promotion and turnover by race/gender) for 511,382 U.S. firms at the firm-occupation-year level.
Potential Use Cases: Workplace diversity and inequality research; promotion/turnover dynamics; linking DEI measures to firm outcomes and asset prices
Region/Coverage: United States (firms observed via public LinkedIn profiles)
Update Frequency: Research release (see SSRN paper for versioning/updates)
Data Format/Access: Downloadable files via Google Drive; accompanying SSRN paper
Authors (if provided): Letian Zhang; Simeng Wang; Yoon Jae Shin

Description: Downloadable datasets used by Robert J. Shiller, including monthly U.S. stock price, dividends, earnings, interest rates and CAPE series starting in 1871, plus historical U.S. housing price data (incl. Case-Shiller related series).
Potential Use Cases: Long-run valuation (CAPE) and return predictability; bubble and crash studies; historical housing market research
Time Span: Stocks: Jan 1871present (monthly); Housing series: historical (e.g., 1890present, depending on file)
Authors (if provided): Robert J. Shiller (and collaborators for specific series, e.g., Karl Case on housing indices)

Dataset Name: Joint Organisations Data Initiative (JODI)  Oil & Gas Data
Description: International oil and natural gas statistics portal with downloadable data, documentation, and an update calendar for participating economies.
Potential Use Cases: Oil & gas market monitoring; macro/commodity research; supply-demand and trade flow analysis
Time Span: Varies by series/country (primarily monthly time series)

Description: Official U.S. labor statistics (e.g., CPI, employment/unemployment, wages) with multiple data tools and a public data API.
Potential Use Cases: Macro-labor empirical research; inflation and wage dynamics; building macro controls; teaching and replication
Update Frequency: Scheduled releases (varies by program; many monthly/quarterly)
Source/Institution: U.S. Department of Labor  Bureau of Labor Statistics

Dataset Name: International Banking Library  Data (curated database portal)
Description: Curated portal summarizing and linking to multiple databases for research on international banking (e.g., cross-border banking, bank balance sheets, regulation, systemic risk indicators).
Potential Use Cases: Finding/choosing banking and regulation datasets; literature replication; assembling cross-country banking panels
Data Format/Access: Web portal with links to underlying datasets

Description: Compilation of historical datasets on the international monetary system, including currency composition of reserves, debt and oil markets, sanctions, invoicing, and exchange rates; some datasets are updated over time.
Potential Use Cases: Reserve currency dominance and transitions; historical international finance; sanctions and exchange-rate research
Time Span: Multiple datasets spanning historical periods (e.g., 18902024 for reserve composition series, depending on dataset)
Update Frequency: Mixed (some datasets updated regularly; others added over time)
Authors (if provided): Barry Eichengreen; Arnaud Mehl; Livia Chiţu (and coauthors by dataset)

Dataset Name: Currency Factors (Currency portfolios & FX factor returns)
Description: Data portal providing currency portfolio excess returns and FX factor returns (gross and net), freely accessible for academic research; accompanied by related working papers.
Potential Use Cases: FX carry/value/momentum factor research; building international risk factors; teaching international asset pricing
Region/Coverage: Global currency samples (e.g., G10, G20; plus broader samples defined in the project)
Time Span: Monthly FX excess returns (sample period varies by file/paper)
Update Frequency: Regular intervals (project states intent to update as new data are released)
Authors (if provided): Pasquale Della Corte; Steven J. Riddiough

Description: Free Excel add-in from the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis that enables one-click download and refresh of FRED time series (hundreds of thousands of series from many sources) directly in Excel.
Potential Use Cases: Rapid macro data collection; building teaching datasets; reproducible macro time-series pipelines in Excel
Region/Coverage: Global (FRED aggregates series from many providers)
Data Format/Access: Excel add-in; time-series downloads into spreadsheets
Source/Institution: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis (FRED)

Dataset Name: Julien Pénasse  Data (Measuring Macroeconomic Tail Risk)
Description: Research data linked to “Measuring Macroeconomic Tail Risk” (with Roberto Marfè), including country crisis probabilities (19002019 for 42 countries) and a long-run proxy for the Martin (2017) bound on the equity premium (Jan 1874Dec 2018).
Potential Use Cases: Macro tail risk and crisis prediction; long-run equity premium bounds; cross-country macro-finance panels
Region/Coverage: 42 countries (for crisis probabilities); long-run series for equity premium bound proxy
Data Format/Access: Replication package (Mendeley) and downloadable data links (Dropbox)

Dataset Name: Climate Change Risk Measures (Skiadopoulos et al.)
Description: Daily market-wide climate change risk measures (textual measures based on Reuters climate-related news); includes an updated daily dataset spanning 3 Jan 200029 Dec 2025.
Potential Use Cases: Climate risk pricing in equities; news-based factor construction; risk management and asset management applications
Region/Coverage: Market-wide measures (developed in the context of U.S. stocks research)
Data Format/Access: Google Sheets downloads/links from the author site
Authors (if provided): George Skiadopoulos; Renato Faccini; Rastin Matin

Dataset Name: Laurens Swinkels  Data (Global market portfolio & related datasets)
Description: Repository of datasets used in Laurens Swinkels research, including (among others) data for the global multi-asset market portfolio (Doeswijk, Lam & Swinkels) and other return series; some datasets are annually updated.
Potential Use Cases: Global market portfolio construction; benchmarking multi-asset returns; factor premium studies and replication
Time Span: Varies by dataset (e.g., global multi-asset market portfolio series referenced as 1959-2012; others extend further)
Update Frequency: Mixed (some datasets annually updated; others static)
Data Format/Access: Download links to datasets (often DOI-linked repositories) and external data repositories
Source/Institution: Laurens Swinkels / Erasmus University Rotterdam (via linked repository pages)
Authors (if provided): Laurens Swinkels; Ronald Doeswijk; Trevin Lam (and coauthors by dataset)
